head.title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Judge Upholds Acid Rain Standards

hedline.hl1: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Judge Upholds Acid Rain Standards

body.head.byline: By Kirk Semple (NYT); Compiled by George James

abstract.p: Justice Bernard J Malone Jr upholds New York State air pollution law that seeks to reduce power plant emissions of nitrogen oxide and sulfur dioxide, main components of acid rain (S)

block.p: A state judge yesterday upheld state air pollution regulations that seek to reduce power plant emissions of nitrogen oxides and sulfur dioxide, main components of acid rain. The state enacted the rules on Oct. 1 on an emergency basis while it followed a parallel procedure to make them permanent, arguing that further delay would endanger public health and the state's natural resources. Four labor unions and a group of commercial and industrial electricity customers had sought an injunction, but Justice Bernard J. Malone Jr. of the State Supreme Court in Albany said the state ''acted rationally'' in enacting the rules. In an interview, Erin M. Crotty, commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation, called the decision ''a significant victory'' for the health of New York's residents and natural resources.
